title: Aerial photos and videos reveal the extent of Hurricane Dorian's destruction in the Bahamas
text:
Hurricane Dorian is finally moving away from the Bahamas after stalling over the islands on Sunday and Monday. The record-breaking storm thrashed the northwestern Bahamas with winds as high as 185 mph, up to 30 inches of rain, and a storm surge that reached 23 feet in some places.

At least five people have been killed.

Read more: Hurricane Dorian is slowly inching from the Bahamas toward the US, leaving devastation in its wake

Prime Minister Hubert Minnis called Dorian's prolonged stay over the Bahamas " a historic tragedy." Few places on Earth have experienced the powerful eyewall of a Category 4 or 5 hurricane for longer than 36 hours, as the island of Grand Bahama did this week.

"The devastation is unprecedented," Minnis told reporters on Monday.

"We are already hearing from residents that whole towns have been wiped out and devastated," Kevin D. Harris, director general of the Bahamas Information Center, told the New York Times. "This is going to be a big search-and-rescue and rebuilding effort. I don't think we have seen anything as bad as this. This one is for the history books."

An aerial photo from a helicopter shows flooding caused by Hurricane Dorian damage on Andros Island in the Bahamas, September 2, 2019. Coast Guard Air Station Clearwater /US Coast Guard / Handout

Rescue efforts are underway, though many government vehicles were flooded by the hurricane's storm surge. Emergency-response offices have received at least 200 calls from people stranded in attics or on roofs, the New York Times reported.

"Some of the bigger vehicles, dump trucks, and fire engines are trying to get through the water," Harris said.

The video below was captured as pilot Terry Power surveyed the damage. People on his aircraft said the fire station and airport are gone or underwater.

Travis Carroll, an assistant editor at The Nassau Guardian, tweeted the image below from the Abaco Islands, where Dorian made landfall on Sunday.

The Red Cross has estimated that 13,000 houses were destroyed in the hurricane.

The National Hurricane Center (NHC) expects hurricane-force winds and storm surge to continue on Grand Bahama through Tuesday evening.
description: New images reveal a "historic tragedy" in the Bahamas. Hurricane Dorian made landfall there as a Category 5 storm on Sunday night.
